title: FEATURE: UN's mission to keep plastics out of oceans and marine life
body: "Plastic pollution is surfing onto Indonesian beaches, settling onto the ocean floor at the North Pole, and rising through the food chain onto our dinner tables," the agency known as UN Environment Programme has said.In 1950, the world's population of 2.5 billion produced 1.5 million tons of plastic; in 2016, a global population of more than 7 billion people produced over 300 million tons of ...
readable_content: - I'm going to focus on a #CleanSeas campaign to reduce plastic pollution and protect marine life. This text discusses the alarming prediction that there will be more plastic than fish in the world's oceans by 2050, and showcases the United Nations' efforts to address this issue. The UN aims to achieve a global ban on microbeads in personal care and cosmetic products by 2022, as well as a drastic reduction in the production and use of single-use plastic. In addition, upcoming events like the Ocean Conference and the efforts of UNEP Patron for Oceans, Lewis Pugh, are highlighted. These initiatives are part of the broader goal to preserve marine resources and achieve Sustainable Development Goal 14.
summary:
The text expresses strong concern about the impact of plastic pollution on marine life and the overall health of the oceans. It highlights the United Nations' proactive measures to reduce plastic waste, with a focus on eliminating microbeads and single-use plastics. The tone is urgent and determined, emphasizing the importance of global action to address this critical issue.
